Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Printed Bioelectronic Solutions for Food Allergens
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is an improvement in the safety of food products. In particular, this I-Corps project aims to identify a customer base for a novel biosensing technology using printed floating-gate transistors (FGTs). FGTs are a platform-technology that can be used to detect any analyte that can be captured using an antibody or a special sequence of single-stranded DNA, known as a DNA aptamer. The most likely direction for commercialization is gluten detection. The growing industry of gluten-free foods is valued at $2.8 billion/year. These foods are critical to people suffering from celiac disease, which affects 1% of the population. The FGT platform can also be adapted to other allergens, clinically relevant proteins, or even microorganisms. The continued advancement and commercialization of this technology thus has broader impacts in food safety, and potentially for biomedical and clinical environments.

This I-Corps project is motivated by the development of a new transistor-based sensing strategy that combines printed electronic and microfluidic technologies. Existing transistor-based sensing technologies pose a difficult materials science problem, wherein the transistor material needs to have outstanding electronic properties as well as stability in the biosensing environment. In contrast, the sensor electronics in the technology under development here are decoupled from the fluidic environment through a side-gate architecture. Published research has established that this platform can detect DNA and proteins. It is thus a flexible platform for biosensing. The research in this project focuses on customer discovery to identify promising directions for commercialization. The initial customer discovery will focus on the food safety industry, with the aim of determining whether gluten detection is the optimal entry point to this market. Subsequent activities will broaden the customer discovery efforts to identify targets in the biomedical and clinical areas.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this I-Corps project was to determine the commercial feasibility for using a floating-gate transistor (FGT) sensing technology, developed at the University of Minnesota, for applications in the food safety space. The Entrepreneurial Lead and Principal Investigator conducted over 120 customer discovery interviews through the course of this project to determine a promising application for the technology. The initial hypothesis was that the FGT technology would be best suited for gluten detection, most notably because the technical feasibility was already demonstrated. The training received in the Bay Area kick-off meeting convinced the team that existing technological feasibility was not the most important part of making a start-up company around the technology. Rather, the team should engage in customer discovery activities to determine the best target molecule that can make a business model, and then determine whether that molecule is feasible for the technology. The resulting customer discovery activities revealed that glyphosate, the active ingredient in RoundUp and used widely as a crop desiccant, is a considerably more promising target for market penetration with the FGT sensor than gluten. Subsequent technical feasibility studies during the course of the project demonstrated that the FGT sensor can indeed detect glyphosate at environmentally relevant levels and in the RoundUp formulation. Additional business plan development activities identified a feasible strategy for starting up a company around this technology, a potential early-stage investor, and an earlyvangelist who was interested in using the technology immediately. However, the Entrepreneurial Lead ultimately chose not to pursue commercializing the technology through a start-up company.  The team continues to pursue licensing opportunities enabled by the deep understanding of the commercial landscape through this I-Corps project.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the identification of a market entry point for the FGT technology and demonstration of the technical feasibility of the device.

The broader impacts include the professional development for both the Entrepreneurial Lead and The Principal Investigator, both of whom received extensive training in entrepreneurship and the lean start-up mentality through this program. While the end result of the project was an informed no-go decision on a company using the FGT for glyphosate detection, the FGT technology remains a viable platform for food safety applications. The skills provided by the I-Corps program will prove useful if the Principal Investigator pursues further commercialization opportunities for the technology, and the use of the FGT in the food safety space could have broad impacts on food security in the United States.

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2018
Modified by: Kevin D Dorfman
